abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Highway Project for Argentina
            successfully met its objective of upgrading key sections of
            Argentina's highway network despite cost overruns and
            long delays in completing certain road sections. These
            problems were mainly due to the country's difficult
            political and economic circumstances experienced during
            project implementation. The overall estimated economic rate
            of return is less than that expected at appraisal (17
            percent versus 24 percent). The difference is explained by
            the extended construction period with consequent inflation,
            and the thus far disappointing traffic growth on some of the
            project roads. Although construction of the Campana-Rio Tala
            expressway could be considered premature because of high
            cost overruns, construction of the remaining road sections
            proved to be justified. The project's biggest impact
            has been through the construction of Route 14, the spine
            road of Mesopotamia, which effectively contributed to the
            development of this important region. The paving of nine
            other earth and gravel roads helped to integrate various
            regions with the major traffic corridors. Although traffic
            development on the expressways was below appraisal
            expectations in the initial year following construction,
            this report expects these modern facilities to facilitate
            the growth of major industrial and commercial centers.
            Furthermore, the project contributed significantly toward
            the development of local consultant capabilities. The report
            concludes that, under difficult circumstances, Argentina
            completed this major construction program successfully and
            that the Borrower's capability to administer and
            supervise large highway programs has now reached maturity,
            having overcome the great difficulties encountered in the mid-1970s.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Argentine economy's transport
            needs are being increasingly met by the highways. The
            national and provincial primary road network consists of
            137,000 km and carries about 36 percent of the total freight
            traffic. Investment in primary roads during the last decade
            has been substantial but the more systematic planning
            introduced for the transport sector during the last two
            years is expected to assist in ensuring a more rational use
            of resources. Highway users at present amply pay for the
            cost of the interurban highway system. In order to improve
            transport coordination and planning further, the Argentine
            authorities propose to strengthen Vialidad Nacional and the
            Sectoral Development Office in the Secretariat of Public
            Works and Transport. They also propose to review the present
            system of allocating resources among the national and
            various provincial road organizations.
